title: 114_s2134
content: The Act titled "Grow Our Own Directive: Physician Assistant Employment and Education Act of 2015" establishes a pilot program to provide educational assistance to physician assistants employed at the Department of Veterans Affairs. The "Grow Our Own Directive" pilot program provides educational assistance to former members of the Armed Forces to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals receive information on application requirements and a list of participating entities. The pilot program offers educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have medical or military health experience, a degree in a health-related field, and have participated in healthcare delivery. The pilot program offers educational assistance to former Armed Forces members to become physician assistants at the Department of Veterans Affairs. Eligible individuals must have a degree in a health-related field, healthcare delivery experience, and not hold a doctorate in medicine, osteopathy, or dentistry. The program will run for five years after 180 days from the enactment of the Act. The pilot program will run for five years starting 180 days after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary will select at least 250 eligible individuals to participate, giving priority to those who were part of the Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program. The Secretary will prioritize individuals who participated in the Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program and those who agree to work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration in designated medically underserved communities. The pilot program prioritizes individuals who participated in the Intermediate Care Technician Pilot Program and those who agree to work as a physician assistant for the Veterans Health Administration in designated medically underserved communities with a high percentage of veterans in the population. The pilot program offers educational assistance for individuals to obtain a master's degree in physician assistant studies or a similar field, using existing programs like the Department of Veterans Affairs Health Professionals Educational Assistance Program. The Secretary will provide at least 35 scholarships annually to individuals participating in the pilot program under the Department of Veterans Affairs Health Professionals Educational Assistance Program. Each participant must enter into an agreement for a period of obligated service. The Secretary will provide scholarships to individuals in the pilot program for obligated service as physician assistants in the Veterans Health Administration. The pilot program specifies a period of obligated service for participants. If no period is specified, a three-year obligation is required. Participants in the pilot program must fulfill a specified period of obligated service. Failure to do so will result in liability to the United States for the amount paid or payable to the individual under the program. The liability for failing to complete the obligated service in the pilot program is determined based on the proportion of days served compared to the total days in the obligated service period. Physician assistant mentors are available for program participants. The Secretary ensures physician assistant mentors are available for participants in the pilot program at Veterans Health Administration facilities. The Secretary also seeks partnerships with accredited institutions offering master's degree programs in physician assistant studies. The pilot program requires accredited institutions to guarantee seats in their master's degree program for participants who meet entrance requirements and provide information on admissions criteria. The pilot program requires accredited institutions to guarantee seats in their master's degree program for participants who meet entrance requirements and provide information on admissions criteria. Other institutions offering programs in physician assistant studies accredited by the Accreditation Review Commission on Education for the Physician Assistant, the Transition Assistance Program of the Department of Defense, the Veterans' Employment and Training Service of the Department of Labor, and programs under chapter 41 of title 38, United States Code for marketing and advertising purposes are also included. The Department of Labor administers programs under chapter 41 of title 38, United States Code, to market and advertise the pilot program to veterans and members of the Armed Forces. The Secretary appoints a Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants within the Office of Physician Assistant Services of the Veterans Health Administration. A Deputy Director for Education and Career Development of Physician Assistants, who is a physician assistant, veteran, and employed by the Department, oversees a pilot program, recruits candidates, and assists participants in applying. A Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention oversees a pilot program, assists participants in applying for a master's degree program, provides information to eligible individuals, and may work at a medical center of the Department. A Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, who is a physician assistant and a veteran employed by the Department, is responsible for coordinating the needs of a pilot program and providing mentors to participants. The pilot program participants are coordinated by the Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, who also works with facilities of the Veterans Health Administration to identify employment positions and mentors. Recruiters report to the Deputy Director and collaborate with Workforce Management. The administrative assistant, reporting to the Deputy Director of Recruitment and Retention, collaborates with various offices to develop national recruiting plans for physician assistants within the Veterans Health Administration. The assistant also provides administrative support for the pilot program. The administrative assistant supports the pilot program in the Office of Physician Assistant Services by assisting with administrative duties. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will submit a report on the pilot program to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will submit a report to Congress on the pilot program in the Office of Physician Assistant Services, evaluating its effectiveness in improving eligible individuals' ability to become physician assistants and achieving program goals. The pilot program aims to enable individuals with medical skills from the Armed Forces to enter the physician assistant workforce of the Department and help address the shortage of physician assistants employed by the Department. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs, along with other key officials, will identify modifications to the program. The pilot program aims to assist individuals with medical skills from the Armed Forces to enter the physician assistant workforce of the Department. Key officials will assess the program's potential as a model for other Department programs. At least $8,000,000 of funding for the pilot program will be sourced accordingly. The pilot program aims to assist individuals with medical skills from the Armed Forces to enter the physician assistant workforce of the Department. Not less than $8,000,000 of the funding will be sourced from amounts appropriated to the Department of Veterans Affairs before the enactment of this Act. Establishment of standards for the Department of Veterans Affairs to use educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will establish standards to improve the use of educational assistance programs for training and hiring physician assistants within the Department of Veterans Affairs. Directors of medical centers will be held accountable for not utilizing the educational assistance effectively. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will hold medical center directors accountable for not using educational assistance programs to advance and retain physician assistants. The Department of Veterans Affairs Education Debt Reduction Program will be available for participants in the pilot program to fill vacant physician positions. Chapter 76 allows participants in the pilot program to fill vacant physician assistant positions by including the Education Debt Reduction Program in vacancy announcements and informing applicants of their eligibility. Compliance with educational assistance programs is monitored. The Education Debt Reduction Program includes monitoring compliance with educational assistance programs and creating incentives for Department of Veterans Affairs employees to apply to physician assistant programs. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out this section. Establishment of pay grades for physician assistants of the Department of Veterans Affairs and requirement to provide competitive pay. The text discusses the establishment of pay grades for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs and the requirement for competitive pay. It also includes amendments to include physician assistants in the competitive pay section and the development of a National Strategic Plan by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is tasked with implementing a national strategic plan for the retention and recruitment of physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs, ensuring competitive pay compared to the private sector. A report must be submitted within one year of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must implement a national strategic plan for physician assistants in the Department of Veterans Affairs, ensuring competitive pay compared to the private sector. A report on the plan's implementation must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs within one year of the Act's enactment.
